{{Infobox video game |title = The Political Machine |image = The Political Machine Coverart.png |developer = [[Stardock]] |publisher = [[Ubisoft]] |designer = |engine = |released = {{vgrelease|NA|August 12, 2004}} |genre = [[Government simulation game|Government simulation]] |modes = [[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }}
'''''The Political Machine''''' is a [[government simulation game]] from [[Stardock]] and the first game in the ''[[The Political Machine (series)|Political Machine]]'' series, in which the player leads a [[election campaign|campaign]] to elect the [[President of the United States]]. The player accomplishes this goal by traveling from state to state and engaging in a variety of activities to either raise money or raise [[Opinion poll|poll]] numbers.
Each game starts with the selection of a pre-created candidate or creation of a fictional candidate from one of the two major American political parties, the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] and the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]].
Headquarters and [[fundraisers]] are possible, the effectiveness of which depends on various factors.
When enough money is accumulated the player can "invest" it in [[campaign advertising|advertisements]] (either through newspapers, radio, or [[television advertisement|TV media]]). The effectiveness of these ads are determined by several factors. For instance, an ad supporting [[tax cuts]] will work better with Republican [[Texas]] than with Democratic [[Massachusetts]].
A key factor in the game is the concept of "Stamina" and "Turns." In each turn, representing one week, a candidate has a set amount of stamina to engage in activities. For example, establishing or upgrading a campaign HQ costs more stamina than creating a newspaper ad.
A sequel, ''[[The Political Machine 2008]]'', was released June 16, 2008, with new characters introduced, such as [[Barack Obama]] and [[John McCain]].
A second sequel, ''[[The Political Machine 2012]]'', was released July 31, 2012, with new characters introduced, such as Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum.
A third sequel, ''[[The Political Machine 2016]]'', was released February 4, 2016, with new characters introduced.
==Candidates==
===Basic candidates===
====Democrats==== [[Image:ChloePolitcalMachine.png|right|thumb|300px|Chloe Sullivan has several strong areas as a candidate, but suffers from a lack of experience.]] *[[Bill Clinton]] *[[Hillary Clinton]] *[[John Edwards]] *[[Al Gore]] *Jeffory Jackson (fictitious character based on politician and 1984 and 1988 presidential candidate [[Jesse Jackson]]) *[[John Kerry]] *Chloe Sullivan (fictitious character, possibly named after [[Chloe Sullivan|a character]] from the television series ''[[Smallville]]'') *[[Tom Vilsack]]
====Republican==== *[[Barbara Bush (First Lady)|Barbara Bush]] *[[George H. W. Bush]] *[[George W. Bush]] *[[Laura Bush]] *[[Dick Cheney]] *Mike Forbes (fictitious character based on 1996 and 2000 presidential candidate [[Steve Forbes]]) *Bill Mason (although there is a [[Bill Mason]], he is not related to politics. The computer game character is based on the 1996 Republican presidential Nominee [[Bob Dole]]) *[[Condoleezza Rice]] *[[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]
===Unlockable candidates=== These candidates have to be defeated by a member of the opposite party in Campaign Mode in order to unlock them.
====Democrat==== *[[Wesley Clark]] *[[Jimmy Carter]] *[[Bill Richardson]] *[[Dick Gephardt]] *[[Lyndon B. Johnson]] *[[Woodrow Wilson]] (mislabeled as from Georgia. Although he spent much of his childhood there, Wilson was elected from New Jersey, where he served as governor.) *[[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] *[[Thomas Jefferson]] (member of the [[Democratic-Republicans]], predecessors to the Democrats)
====Republican==== *[[William Taft]] *[[Gerald Ford]] *[[Ulysses S. Grant]] *[[Richard Nixon]] *[[Theodore Roosevelt]] (mislabeled as from Ohio) *[[Ronald Reagan]] *[[Abraham Lincoln]] *[[George Washington]] (sympathetic to the [[Federalists]], predecessors to the [[Whig Party (United States)|Whigs]], and in turn the Republicans)
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 72/100<ref name=MC>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/the-political-machine |title=The Political Machine for PC Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=December 23, 2014}}</ref> | 1UP = C<ref>{{cite web |author=1UP staff |date=October 28, 2004 |url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/political-machine |title=[The] Political Machine |publisher=[[1UP.com]] |accessdate=April 24, 2016}}</ref> | CGW = {{Rating|4.5|5}}<ref>{{cite journal |last=Geryk |first=Bruce |url=http://www.cgwmuseum.org/galleries/issues/cgw_244.pdf |title=The Political Machine |magazine=[[Computer Gaming World]] |issue=244 |date=November 2004 |page=84 |accessdate=April 24, 2016}}</ref> | GI = 7/10<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Political Machine |magazine=[[Game Informer]] |issue=139 |date=November 2004 |page=167}}</ref> | GameRev = C−<ref>{{cite web |last=Ferris |first=Duke |date=September 3, 2004 |url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/the-political-machine |title=The Political Machine Review |publisher=[[Game Revolution]] |accessdate=December 23, 2014}}</ref> | GSpot = 7.4/10<ref>{{cite web |last=Todd |first=Brett |date=August 18, 2004 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/the-political-machine-review/1900-6105145/ |title=The Political Machine Review |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=December 23, 2014}}</ref> | GSpy = {{Rating|4|5}}<ref>{{cite web |last=Chick |first=Tom |date=August 24, 2004 |url=http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/the-political-machine/541810p1.html |title=GameSpy: The Political Machine |publisher=[[GameSpy]] |accessdate=December 23, 2014}}</ref> | GameZone = 7.5/10<ref>{{cite web |last=McElfish |first=Carlos |date=August 25, 2004 |url=http://www.gamezone.com/reviews/the_political_machine_pc_review |title=The Political Machine - PC - Review |publisher=GameZone |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080417214130/http://pc.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r23757.htm |archivedate=April 17, 2008 |deadurl=no |accessdate=December 23, 2014}}</ref> | IGN = 7.9/10<ref>{{cite web |last=McNamara |first=Tom |date=September 20, 2004 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/09/20/the-political-machine-review |title=The Political Machine Review |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=December 23, 2014}}</ref> | PCF = 82%<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Political Machine |magazine=[[PC Format]] |issue=167 |date=November 2004}}</ref> | PCGUS = 73%<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Political Machine |magazine=[[PC Gamer]] |date=December 2004 |page=96}}</ref> }}
The game received "average" reviews according to video game [[review aggregator]] [[Metacritic]].<ref name=MC/>
The editors of ''[[Computer Gaming World]]'' nominated ''The Political Machine'' as their 2004 "Strategy Game of the Year (General)", although it lost to ''[[The Sims 2]]''. They wrote, "[W]e were enamored with Stardock's ''The Political Machine'', which let us run the 2004 presidential campaign in a way that was far more fun than its real-life counterpart."<ref name=cgwpremier2004>{{cite journal | author=Editors of ''CGW'' | journal=[[Computer Gaming World]] | title=2004 Games of the Year |date=March 2005 | issue=249 | pages=56–67 }}</ref> ''The Political Machine'' won ''[[Computer Games Magazine]]''{{'}}s 2004 "Best Budget Game" award.<ref name=cgm14th>{{cite journal | author=Staff | journal=[[Computer Games Magazine]] | title=The Best of 2004; The 14th Annual ''Computer Games'' Awards |date=March 2005 | issue=172 | pages=48–56 }}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=February 2009}} The '''White Nationalist Party''' (WNP) was a [[neo-fascism|neo-fascist]] [[United Kingdom|British]] [[political party]], founded in May 2002 as "the British political wing of Aryan Unity".<ref>Sykes, Alan ''The Radical Right in Britain'' Palgrave (2005), p 147</ref><ref>[http://www.aryanunity.com/WNP/wnpintro.html Aryan Unity website]</ref> ==Development==
The party was formed by [[Eddy Morrison]], and [[Kevin Watmough]] "a key figure in [[Combat 18]]" and webmaster of [[Redwatch]];<ref>[http://www.searchlightmagazine.com/index.php?link=template&story=37 Searchlight Magazine]</ref> the new party was effectively the [[Yorkshire]] branch of the [[National Front (UK)|National Front]], and the party conducted most of its activities in Yorkshire. The national youth leader of the White Nationalist Party was Ronnie Cooper, a teen from the South Yorkshire area who was exposed for his fascist beliefs by the ''Sunday People'' newspaper in 2003. Cooper is now understood to be a serving member of the Royal Navy.
Although largely Yorkshire-based it also sought to expand elsewhere. In 2003 the group applied to march in [[Glasgow]] but it was rejected by the city council.<ref>{{Cite news |last= Davidson |title= TALKING POLITICS: White Nationalist Party. |newspaper= [[Sunday Mirror]] {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} |accessdate= 3 November 2014 |date= 21 September 2003 |first= Lorraine |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-107977093.html }}</ref>
The WNP also sought to campaign in amongst [[Ulster loyalism|loyalists]] in [[Northern Ireland]], posting stickers and delivering leaflets in [[Ballymena]], [[Coleraine]], [[Antrim town]] and [[Ballymoney]] in the run-up to [[the Twelfth]] in 2003.<ref>{{Cite news |last= Kelly |title= Racists' campaign 'must be stopped' Drive for recruits sparks concern |newspaper= [[Belfast Telegraph]] {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} |accessdate= 3 November 2014 |date= 6 June 2003 |first= Kim |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-10692232.html }}</ref> The group, which emphasised its anti-[[Irish republican]] nature by using slogans such as "hang IRA scum" in its literature, claimed to have 80 members in the province in May of that year.<ref>{{Cite news |last= Kelly |title= Right-wing group targets Ballymoney |newspaper= [[Belfast Telegraph]] {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} |accessdate= 3 November 2014 |date= 16 May 2003 |first= Kim |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-10686265.html }}</ref> In a move condemned by local politicians WNP flags were also placed on lampposts in Ballymena around the same time.<ref>{{Cite news |last= |title= Racist fears heighten as Nazi flags flown.(News) |newspaper= [[The News Letter]] {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} |accessdate= 3 November 2014 |date= 24 July 2003 |first= |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-105763845.html }}</ref> Most of the party's stickers and flags were removed by parties of residents organised in opposition by the loyalist [[Progressive Unionist Party]], which publicly condemned racism.<ref name="rock"/>
In 2004 the party also revealed plans to host a [[Blood & Honour]] music festival in Northern Ireland although a counter-campaign was organised to encourage venues to turn down the booking.<ref name="rock">{{Cite news |last= |title= Opposition to 'fascist' rock gig growing Website warns of plans for concert |newspaper= [[Belfast Telegraph]] {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} |accessdate= 3 November 2014 |date= 18 May 2004 |first= |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-10705048.html }}</ref> The proposed gigs did not take place however.
The WNP was severely weakened in 2004 when the [[England First Party]] (EFP) broke away under [[Mark Cotterill]]. The WNP had intended to use that name when the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] refused to register WNP as an official name;<ref>[http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2003-4/uk.htm Article on Anti-Semitic groups]</ref> but after a dispute between Cotterill on the one side and [[Eddy Morrison]] and [[John G. Wood]] (the WNP's national organiser) on the other, the EFP group broke away to become a separate, English nationalist, party.
The WNP under Morrison and John G. Wood courted [[John Tyndall (politician)|John Tyndall]], although he refused {{Citation needed|reason=where is this claimed?|date=December 2008}} to join as he did not feel that divisions were helpful. Eventually Eddy Morrison left the party and with John G. Wood and Kevin Watmough in 2005 formed the similar [[British Peoples Party (2005)|British People's Party]].
==Policies and ideology==
The White Nationalist Party's inspiration was "unashamedly nationalist socialist" and opposed to "all democracy".<ref>Sykes, Alan ''The Radical Right in Britain'' Palgrave (2005), p 148</ref> The WP had a list of 32 policies,<ref>[http://www.aryanunity.com/WNP/policies.html Policies of the White Nationalist Party]</ref> based on principles which included repatriation, opposition to [[populism]], [[Zionism]] and [[homosexuality]], and adherence to [[David Lane (white nationalist)|David Lane]]'s [[fourteen words]].<ref>[http://www.aryanunity.com/WNP/nocompromise.html White Nationalist Party website]</ref> The group is now vehemently opposed to the [[British National Party]], viewing them as [[Race traitor|race traitors]].<ref>[http://www.aryanunity.com/WNP/griffinfile1.html Anti-Griffin page]</ref>

{{Infobox organization | name = Neoi Prasinoi | native_name = Νέοι Πράσινοι | former_name = | image = [[File:LogoNeoiPrasinoi.jpg|300px]] | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | map = | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date|2008}} | founder = <!-- or | founders = --> | extinction = <!-- {{End date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | merged = | type = [[Green politics|Green]] | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = <!-- focus as e.g. humanitarian, peacekeeping, etc --> | professional_title = <!-- for professional associations --> | headquarters = | location = | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using {{Coord}} --> | region_served = | services = | membership = | language = | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | leader_title = President | leader_name = Coordination Committee | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = [[Federation of Young European Greens]] | subsidiaries = | affiliations = [[Global Greens]] [https://www.facebook.com/pages/MADA-Mediterranean-Aid-and-Development-Alliance-Network/200106030113640?fref=ts MADA network] | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers= | slogan = | website = {{URL|neoiprasinoi.blogspot.gr}} | remarks = | footnotes = }} Neoi Prasinoi ({{lang-el|Νέοι Πράσινοι}}, Young Greens) is a non-partisan political youth organization in Greece, a member of the [[Federation of Young European Greens]], consisting of ecologically and politically restless youngsters. The Federation of Young European Greens is the Youth Wing of the [[European Green Party]].
==History & Aims== Neoi Prasinoi were founded by young members of the [[Ecologist Greens]] in January 2008, rather than by the party itself. Neoi Prasinoi have entered a transitional period in July 2014 with the direct election of the temporary Coordination Committee, mandated with the realization of the decisions of the 15th of July. These decisions included reforming Neoi Prasinoi into a non-partisan political youth in Greece, as well as the preparation of a Statute for Neoi Prasinoi. The term of the temporary Coordination Committee ended at the 1st Conference of Neoi Prasinoi, which adopted the Statute and elected a Coordination Committee with a full term. Neoi Prasinoi are to this day the only non-partisan political youth in Greece, a pioneering endeavour in itself.
Neoi Prasinoi fight climate change and strive for the protection of the environment, animal rights and the sustainability of our societies, without sidelining social liberties, non-violence, [[paideia]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/paideia|title=paideia|publisher=|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref> racism and the rule of law, social justice and democracy
Neoi Prasinoi aim at change through the changing of mentalities and behaviours in our daily lives. They seek to collectively support new models of social relations, far more ecological and with more solidarity. As part of the green movement, they strive to change political choices and priorities, along with the other emancipation.
